THE BANK OF AMERICA PENSION PLAN
FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
AND SUPPLEMENTAL SCHEDULES
WITH INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023

INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT
To the Plan Administrator and Plan Participants of
The Bank of America Pension Plan
Opinion
We have audited the financial statements of The Bank of America Pension Plan (the Plan), an employee
benefit plan subject to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), which
comprise the statements of net assets available for benefits as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the
related statements of changes in net assets available for benefits for the years then ended, and the related
notes to the financial statements (collectively, the financial statements).
In our opinion, the accompanying financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the net
assets available for benefits of the Plan as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the changes in net assets
available for benefits for the years then ended, in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States of America (US GAAP).
Basis for Opinion
We conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States
of America (US GAAS). Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the
Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements section of our report. We are
required to be independent of the Plan and to meet our other ethical responsibilities, in accordance with
the relevant ethical requirements relating to our audits. We believe that the audit evidence we have
obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion.
Responsibilities of Management for the Financial Statements
Plan management (Management) is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the financial
statements in accordance with US GAAP, and for the design, implementation, and maintenance of
internal control relevant to the preparation and fair presentation of financial statements that are free
from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.
In preparing the financial statements, Management is required to evaluate whether there are conditions
or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Plan’s ability to continue
as a going concern for one year after the date that the financial statements are available to be issued.
Management is also responsible for maintaining a current plan instrument, including all plan
amendments, administering the Plan, and determining that the transactions of the Plan that are presented
and disclosed in the financial statements are in conformity with the provisions of the Plan, including
maintaining sufficient records with respect to each of the participants, to determine the benefits due or

Diverse Thinking | Unique Perspectives

and therefore is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with US GAAS will always
detect a material misstatement when it exists. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting
from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery,
intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control. Misstatements are
considered material if there is a substantial likelihood that, individually or in the aggregate, they would
influence the judgment made by a reasonable user based on the financial statements.
In performing an audit in accordance with US GAAS, we:
• Exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit.
• Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due
to fraud or error, and design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks. Such
procedures include examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures
in the financial statements.
• Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit
procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an
opinion on the effectiveness of the internal controls of the Plan. Accordingly, no such opinion
is expressed.
• Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of significant
accounting estimates made by Management, as well as evaluate the overall presentation of the
financial statements.
• Conclude whether, in our judgment, there are conditions or events, considered in the aggregate,
that raise substantial doubt about the ability of the Plan to continue as a going concern for a
reasonable period of time.
We are required to communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters,
the planned scope and timing of the audit, significant audit findings, and certain internal control–related
matters that we identified during the audit.
Other Matter – Supplemental Schedules Required by ERISA
Our audits were conducted for the purpose of forming an opinion on the financial statements as a whole.
The supplemental information in the accompanying Schedule of Assets (Held at End of Year) as of
December 31, 2024, and Schedule of Reportable Transactions for the year then ended, are presented
for purposes of additional analysis and are not a required part of the financial statements but are
supplementary information required by the Department of Labor (DOL)’s Rules and Regulations for
Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA. Such information is the responsibility of Management and was
derived from and relates directly to the underlying accounting and other records used to prepare the
financial statements. The information has been subjected to the auditing procedures applied in the audit
of the financial statements and certain additional procedures, including comparing and reconciling such
information directly to the underlying accounting and other records used to prepare the financial
statements or to the financial statements themselves, and other additional procedures in accordance
with US GAAS.
2

In forming our opinion on the supplemental schedules, we evaluated whether the supplemental
schedules, including their form and content, are presented in conformity with the DOL’s Rules and
Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA.
In our opinion, the supplemental schedules are fairly stated, in all material respects, in relation to the
financial statements as a whole, and the form and content are presented in conformity with the DOL’s
Rules and Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA.

1. Description of the Plan
The following description of The Bank of America Pension Plan (the Plan) is provided for general information
purposes only. Participants should refer to the Plan’s Summary Plan Description and any supplements thereto
for a more complete description of applicable Plan provisions. Other Plan provisions may also apply to
participants from predecessor plans assumed by Bank of America Corporation (the Corporation) and merged
into the Plan.
Plan Sponsor and Participating Employers
The Corporation is the Plan Sponsor. Participating employers in the Plan include the Corporation and certain of
the Corporation’s principal subsidiaries.
Plan Administrator
The Plan is administered by the Bank of America Corporation Corporate Benefits Committee (the Committee).
The Compensation and Human Capital Committee of the Board of Directors of the Corporation delegated to the
Global Human Resources Executive of the Corporation the authority to select members of the Committee.
Members of the Committee serve without compensation and act by majority vote. The Committee has overall
responsibility for the operation and administration of the Plan including the power to construe and interpret the
Plan, decide all questions that arise thereunder and to delegate responsibilities.
Plan Trustee
Bank of America, N.A. (BANA) is the Plan Trustee.
General
The Plan is a defined benefit plan with both traditional and cash balance elements providing retirement,
disability and death benefits to all eligible employees. It is subject to the provisions of the Employee
Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as amended (ERISA).
Pension Benefits
Benefits earned under the Plan have been frozen. The participants’ cash balance accounts (other than their
pre-2008 Pension Accounts, if applicable) continue to earn interest credits. Any pre-2008 Pension Accounts, if
applicable, continue to earn investment credits (gains and losses).
Participants can direct their Pension Account balances attributable to their pre-2008 participation in the Plan
(the directable portion of the Pension Account) among multiple hypothetical investment options, known as
Investment Choices. The Investment Choices are hypothetical investment funds, which are credited with the
actual return received by the corresponding investment funds in The Bank of America 401(k) Plan (the 401(k)
Plan). Through December 31, 2024 and 2023, there were 29 investment funds in the 401(k) Plan available as
Investment Choices.
For pre-2008 Pension Accounts, the Bank of America Common Stock Fund and the Stable Value Fund are not
offered as investment options under the Plan. Although these investments are still offered in the 401(k) Plan,
Internal Revenue Service (IRS) regulations do not permit these Investment Choices in the Plan. These
Investment Choices were replaced by the Corporate Bond Rate Choice which provides a minimum annual
interest crediting rate of at least 4%. The interest crediting rate for the other Investment Choices in the Plan will
be determined by reference to a corresponding subset of Plan assets established within the Trust as defined by
IRS regulations.
The participant’s designated Investment Choices determine the return on the directable portion of the
participant’s Pension Account. Each business day, the directable portion of the participant’s Pension Account
will be credited or debited with an Investment Credit or Debit which represents the net increase or decrease that
would have been realized if the amount in the directable portion of the participant’s Pension Account had been
actually invested in the corresponding investment fund in the 401(k) Plan.
Pension Account balances attributable to compensation credits earned on and after January 1, 2008 continue to
be credited with interest credits based on the average monthly yield of the 10-year U.S. Treasury Constant
Maturity and are not directable among the Investment Choices.
6

The Bank of America Pension Plan
Notes to Financial Statements
December 31, 2024 and 2023
Each participant’s Pension Account represents the amount of the participant’s benefits accrued under the Plan at
any reporting date; however, it does not represent an interest in the assets of the Plan. Assets of the Plan are
managed under the general direction of the Committee, and benefits under the Plan are paid from the assets of
the Plan Trust in accordance with the requirements of the Plan, ERISA and the rules and regulations of the
Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC).
The benefit payable to a participant shall be the accrued vested benefit in the participant’s Pension Account,
subject to minimum amounts, including those guaranteed at conversion, payable in a single cash payment,
monthly annuity option or a combination of both.
Under the terms of the Plan, (i) the initial Pension Account established for all participants and (ii) all
compensation credits are guaranteed against investment loss by the Plan. Additionally, prior to April 16, 2009,
all or a portion of participants’ Transferred Savings Account balances [previously transferred from the 401(k)
Plan and which, as of April 15, 2009, were transferred to The Bank of America Transferred Savings Account
Plan (the TSA Plan)] were guaranteed against investment loss. As of December 31, 2024 and 2023, the
estimated guaranteed minimum benefits were $632 million and $692 million, respectively, for the initial
Pension Account and compensation credits, and $192 million and $226 million, respectively, for the Transferred
Savings Accounts (TSA Balances).
In addition, certain participants in prior defined benefit plans which have merged into the Plan have all or a
portion of their Plan benefit calculated under a prior plan formula, and may receive the larger of the benefit or
the benefit calculated under the current Plan.
Benefits may be funded through an arrangement with an insurance company with the purchase of one or more
annuity contracts. The annuity contract shall provide for the continued payment of benefits to the Designated
Individual (participant or other beneficiary) under the Plan in the same form that was in effect under the Plan
immediately before the annuity purchase. After the annuity purchase, no Designated Individual shall be a
participant and the Plan shall have no further obligation to make any payment with respect to a Designated
Individual's benefits under the Plan. Purchases of annuity contracts during 2024 and 2023 totaled $0 and
$297,777,076, respectively.
Death and Disability Benefits
If an active participant dies in service, the surviving spouse or other beneficiary is entitled to receive a death
benefit equal to the participant’s benefit under the Plan. If an active participant becomes disabled, the
participant continues to accrue benefit service while receiving long-term disability benefits if considered an
employee, up to age 65 or the participant’s death, whichever is earlier.
Transfers to The Bank of America Transferred Savings Account Plan
The Corporation established the TSA Plan on April 15, 2009 for the purpose of holding, administering,
investing and distributing certain amounts transferred from the Plan that had been allocated to participants’ TSA
Balances in the Plan.
TSA Balances in the Plan were eligible for an Investment Guarantee from the Plan, described in more detail
below in the subsection entitled “TSA Investment Guarantee.” When participants received a final distribution of
their TSA Balances, if the TSA Balance was less than the TSA Investment Guarantee, such participants would
receive an additional payment from the Plan equal to the difference. Concurrently with the establishment of the
TSA Plan, the Corporation increased the TSA Investment Guarantee for all current and former participants in
accordance with a specified formula. As a result of that increase, certain participants who had taken a total
distribution of their TSA Balances from the Plan prior to April 15, 2009 became entitled to an additional
payment from the Plan. Because those participants had not yet separated from service, those additional
payments were also transferred to the TSA Plan. TSA Balances in the TSA Plan, other than balances
attributable to participants who had taken a total distribution of their TSA Balances from the Plan prior to April
15, 2009, continue to be eligible for the TSA Investment Guarantee from the Plan.
Additional payments attributable to the excess TSA Investment Guarantee for participants who commenced
benefit payments during 2024 and 2023 totaled $202,025 and $93,509, respectively.
7

The Bank of America Pension Plan
Notes to Financial Statements
December 31, 2024 and 2023
TSA Investment Guarantee
The TSA Investment Guarantee is equal to 111.6% of the value of the original TSA Balance in the Plan at the
time the TSA Plan was created, reduced by the amount of any withdrawals, loans or cash payments of dividends
on Bank of America Corporation common stock, and increased by the amount of repayments of principal on
participant loans. A participant’s TSA Investment Guarantee may be reduced by transfers to an alternate payee
in accordance with a qualified domestic relations order.
If the value of the TSA Investment Guarantee exceeds the value of the TSA Balance at the time a participant
receives a final distribution of his or her TSA Balance, the participant will be entitled to an additional payment
from the Plan in an amount equal to that excess.
In the event a participant withdraws his or her entire TSA Balance prior to separation from service, the amount
of his or her TSA Investment Guarantee remaining, if any, will be transferred from the Plan to the TSA Plan
and credited to the participant’s TSA Investment Guarantee Account. The participant’s balance in his or her
TSA Investment Guarantee Account is not available for distribution until a final distribution is made after
separation from service. Participants are not able to direct the investment of their TSA Investment Guarantee
Account. These funds will remain invested in the Stable Value Fund of the TSA Plan until distributed.
Vesting
A participant whose employment terminated on or after January 1, 2008 is 100% vested after completing 3 or
more years of vesting service. Additionally, a participant becomes 100% vested, regardless of the years of
service, if during employment, the participant reaches age 65, dies, or becomes disabled under the Long-Term
Disability benefits component of the Corporation’s Group Benefits Program, or terminates employment due to
certain divestitures or workforce reductions. Non-vested employees hired prior to the freeze continue to earn
vesting service toward vesting in the Plan while working for the Corporation.
Participant Loans
The Plan has a participant loan program that was only available to participants who were in service as of
December 31, 2005. Effective July 1, 2015, loans were no longer offered to any participants in the Plan. Any
loans outstanding as of July 1, 2015 remain subject to and governed by the applicable terms of the Plan in effect
prior to that date.
Loan repayments are made from payroll deductions. A maximum of two outstanding loans is permitted at any
time. Interest rates on loans are generally calculated based on the prime rate as published by Reuters on the last
business day of the month prior to the month the loan was obtained. Each loan bears an interest rate equal to the
prime rate plus 1% and is fixed for the life of the loan. Interest rates ranged from 4.25% to 10.50% for loans
held by the Plan as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively. Principal residence loans have a term of 1 to
15 years. General purpose loans had a term of 1 to 5 years and are no longer outstanding.
The loans are segregated within the Trust and are included as an investment of the Plan. All participant loan
repayments attributable to the directable portion of the Participant’s Pension Account are hypothetically
invested in the investment designations in effect for the directable portion.
2. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Significant accounting policies of the Plan are summarized below:
Basis of Accounting
The financial statements are prepared on the accrual basis of accounting in accordance with U.S. generally
accepted accounting principles (GAAP). Revenues are recognized as earned. Benefits paid to Plan participants
are recorded when paid. Expenses are recorded as incurred.
Management Estimates
The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and
assumptions that affect the reported amounts of Plan assets, liabilities, and changes therein, the disclosure of
contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and actuarial present value of accumulated
Plan benefits as of the benefit information date. Actual results could differ from those estimates.
8

The Bank of America Pension Plan
Notes to Financial Statements
December 31, 2024 and 2023
Investment Valuation and Income Recognition
Investments are reported at fair value. Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to
transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date (see Note 5:
Fair Value Measurements).
Realized gains (losses) on investment transactions are recorded as the difference between proceeds received and
cost. Cost is determined on the average cost basis.
Net appreciation (depreciation) includes gains and losses on investments bought and sold as well as held during
the year.
Investment securities purchased and sold are recorded on a trade date basis. Interest income is recorded on the
accrual basis. Dividends are recorded on the ex-dividend date.
Foreign Currency
Investment securities and other assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies are translated into U.S.
dollar amounts at date of valuation. Purchases and sales of investment securities and income and expense items
denominated in foreign currencies are translated into U.S. dollar amounts on the respective dates of such
transactions.
The Plan does not isolate that portion of the results of operations resulting from changes in foreign exchange
rates on investments from the fluctuations arising from changes in market prices of securities held. Such
fluctuations are included with the net realized and unrealized gain or loss from investments.
Short Sales
A short sale is a transaction in which the Plan sells securities it does not own (but has borrowed) in anticipation
of a decline in the market price of the securities. When the Plan makes a short sale, the proceeds it receives
from the sale will be held on behalf of the broker affecting the sale until the Plan replaces the borrowed
securities.
To deliver the securities to the buyer, the Plan arranges through the broker to borrow the securities and, in doing
so, the Plan becomes obligated to replace the securities borrowed at their market value at the time of
replacement. The Plan may have to pay a premium to borrow the securities and must pay any dividends or
interest payable on the borrowed securities until the securities are replaced. Cash segregated to cover securities
sold short is included in the statements of net assets available for benefits.
Options
The Plan may use options to enhance investment return, or to hedge against changes in the values of securities
the Plan owns or expects to purchase. Writing puts and buying calls tends to increase the Plan’s exposure to the
underlying instrument, and writing calls or buying puts tends to decrease the Plan’s exposure to the underlying
instrument, or hedge other Plan investments.
For options purchased to hedge the Plan’s investments, the potential risk to the Plan is that the change in value
of options contracts may not correspond to the change in value of the hedged instruments. In addition, losses
may arise from changes in the value of the underlying instruments, if there is an illiquid secondary market for
the contracts, or if the counterparty is unable to perform. The maximum loss for purchased options is limited to
the premium initially paid for the option. For options written by the Plan, the Plan bears the market risk of an
unfavorable change in the price of the security underlying the written option. The potential income for written
options is limited to the amount of premium received.
Participant Loans
Participant loans are measured at their unpaid principal balance plus any accrued but unpaid interest.
Delinquent participant loans are reclassified as benefits paid to participants based upon the terms of the Plan
document.
Group Annuity Contracts
Group annuity contracts which transfer the obligation for the payment of benefits to the insurer are excluded
from Plan assets (see Note 12: Group Annuity Contracts).

Plan Expenses
Trustee direct expenses, PBGC insurance premiums, investment management fees, some professional fees and
certain administrative fees for employee communication and services, recordkeeping and benefit payment
services are paid by the Plan. Other administrative expenses and some professional fees are paid by the
Corporation.
3. Employer Contributions
The Corporation’s policy is to make a contribution to the Plan each year that is between the minimum required
amount (if any) and the maximum deductible amount, as actuarially determined, based on ERISA requirements.
The Corporation did not make any contributions to the Plan in 2024 and 2023. The Corporation met its ERISA
minimum funding requirements for Plan years 2024 and 2023.
4. Risks and Uncertainties
The Plan invests in various investment securities. Investment securities are exposed to various risks such as
interest rate, market and credit risks. Due to the level of risk associated with certain investment securities, it is
at least reasonably possible that changes in the values of investment securities will occur in the near term and
that such changes could materially affect the amounts reported in the Statements of Net Assets Available for
Benefits.
Plan contributions and the actuarial present value of accumulated Plan benefits are reported based on certain
assumptions pertaining to interest rates, inflation rates and employee demographics, all of which are subject to
change. Due to uncertainties inherent in the assumption process, it is at least reasonably possible that changes
in these assumptions in the near term could be material to the financial statements.
5. Fair Value Measurements
Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) 820, Fair Value Measurement, establishes a framework for
measuring fair value. That framework provides a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation
techniques used to measure fair value. The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in
active markets for identical assets or liabilities (level 1 measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable
inputs (level 3 measurements).
The three levels of the fair value hierarchy under ASC 820 are described below:
Level 1 Inputs to the valuation methodology are unadjusted quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in
active markets that the Plan has the ability to access.
Level 2 Inputs to the valuation methodology include:
• Quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets;
• Quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in inactive markets;
• Inputs other than quoted prices that are observable for the asset or liability; and
• Inputs that are derived principally from or corroborated by observable market data by correlation or
other means.
If the asset or liability has a specified (contractual) term, the level 2 input must be observable for
substantially the full term of the asset or liability.
Level 3 Inputs to the valuation methodology are unobservable and significant to the fair value measurement.
The asset’s or liability’s fair value measurement level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level
of any input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
Valuation techniques used need to maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable
inputs.
10

The Bank of America Pension Plan
Notes to Financial Statements
December 31, 2024 and 2023
ASC 820 also includes the measurement of fair value using the NAV as a practical expedient method for certain
investments. The NAV as a practical expedient method uses the net asset value per share of the underlying
investment. Investments for which fair value is measured at net asset value per share using the practical
expedient are not categorized in the fair value hierarchy. The following is a description of the valuation
methodologies used for assets measured at fair value:
• Money market funds are valued at the net asset value of shares held by the Plan at year end and are classified
as level 1 within the fair value hierarchy.
• Interest bearing cash is valued at cost, which approximates fair value and is classified as level 1 within the
fair value hierarchy.
• U.S. government and government agency obligations that are issued or guaranteed by the U.S. Government,
its agencies, authorities and instrumentalities are valued on the basis of prices provided by an independent
pricing service. These investments are generally classified within level 1 of the valuation hierarchy.
Investments in certain U.S. government and government agency obligations, corporate debt and non-U.S.
debt obligations for which prices are not available on the basis of actual trades in securities markets are
valued by an independent pricing service approved by the Plan Sponsor. Valuations may be based upon a
matrix system and/or appraisals provided by the pricing service which accounts for such factors as yields,
prices, maturities, sell features, type of issue, coupon rate, ratings on comparable securities and other factors.
These securities are generally classified as level 2 within the fair value hierarchy.
• Asset-backed securities are valued using the external broker bids where available and are generally classified
as level 2 within the fair value hierarchy.
• Mutual funds are valued at the net asset value of shares held by the Plan at year end and are generally
classified as level 1 within the fair value hierarchy.
• Collective investment funds, which includes pooled separate accounts, are stated at fair value as determined
by the issuers based on the unit values of the funds. Unit values are determined by dividing the funds’ net
assets, which represent the unadjusted prices in active markets of the underlying investments, by the number
of units outstanding at the valuation date. These are classified as level 2 within the fair value hierarchy
unless the unit value of the funds are published less frequently than daily and are eligible for the practical
expedient in which the NAV as a practical expedient method is used.
• Common and preferred stocks and exchange traded funds listed or regularly traded on a securities exchange
are valued at the last quoted sales price at the end of the Plan year and substantially all are classified as level
1 within the fair value hierarchy. Listed securities not priced on a particular day use other independent
pricing sources or broker quotes.
• Real estate investment trusts (REITs) listed or regularly traded on a securities exchange are valued at the last
quoted sales price at the end of the Plan year and substantially all are classified as level 1 within the fair
value hierarchy. Listed securities not priced on a particular day use other independent pricing sources or
broker quotes.
• Limited partnerships are valued based on the NAV as a practical expedient method.
• Participant loans are valued at cost, which approximates fair value. Loans are measured at their unpaid
principal balance plus any accrued but unpaid interest. Interest rates are equal to the prime rate plus 1% and
are fixed for the life of the loan. Since there is no active market for loans to Plan participants they are
classified as level 3 within the fair value hierarchy. The significant unobservable input used in fair value
measurement of the loans is participant utilization of the loan program feature.
• Other investments consist primarily of options and futures whose valuations are described in Notes 2 and 6,
respectively, and are classified as level 2 within the fair value hierarchy. The remaining assets’ fair values
and fair value hierarchies are determined by the Trustee within the framework provided by ASC 820 using
observable market data, an independent pricing service approved by the Plan Sponsor, unobservable inputs
and any other available information.
The methods described above may produce a fair value calculation that may not be indicative of net realizable
value or reflective of future fair values. Furthermore, while the management believes its valuation methods are
appropriate and consistent with other market participants, the use of different methodologies or assumptions to
determine the fair value of certain financial instruments could result in a different fair value measurement at the
reporting date.

6. Derivative Financial Instruments
Financial Futures Contracts
The Plan invests in financial futures contracts solely for the purpose of hedging its existing portfolio securities,
or securities that the Plan intends to purchase, against fluctuations in fair value caused by changes in prevailing
market indices or interest rates. Upon entering into a financial futures contract, the Plan is required to pledge to
the broker an amount of cash and/or other assets equal to a certain percentage of the contract amount (initial
market deposit). Subsequent payments, known as “variation margin,” are made or received by the Plan each
day, depending on the daily fluctuations in the fair value of the underlying security. The Plan recognizes a gain
or loss equal to the daily variation margin, which is recorded in realized gains or losses and included in the
statement of changes in net assets available for benefits in net investment income. The fair value of the Plan’s
financial futures contracts are represented by the estimated unrealized gains or losses as determined by quoted
market prices or dealer quotes. Should market conditions move unexpectedly, the Plan may not achieve the
anticipated benefits of the financial futures contracts and may realize a loss. The use of futures transactions
involves the risk of imperfect correlation in movements in the price of futures contracts, interest rates, and the
underlying hedged assets. The credit risk associated with these contracts is minimal as they are traded on
organized exchanges and settled daily.
As of December 31, 2024 and 2023, the Plan held financial futures contracts with total notional amounts of $1.9
billion and $0.9 billion, respectively. Notional amounts do not quantify risk or represent assets or liabilities of
the Plan, but are used in the calculation of cash settlements under the contracts. The financial futures contracts
are marked-to-market and cash is settled each day. As such, the fair value of the Plan’s financial futures
contracts as of December 31, 2024 and 2023 was $95,695 and $26,126,575, respectively.
Forward Foreign Currency Transactions
The Plan may enter into forward foreign currency exchange contracts primarily to hedge against foreign
currency exchange rate risks on its non-U.S. dollar denominated investment securities. When entering into a
forward currency contract, the Plan agrees to receive or deliver a fixed quantity of foreign currency for an
agreed-upon price on an agreed future date. These contracts are valued daily and the Plan’s net equity therein,
representing unrealized gain or loss on the contracts as measured by the difference between the forward foreign
exchange rates at the dates of entry into the contracts and the forward foreign exchange rates at the reporting
date, is included in the statement of net assets available for benefits. Realized and unrealized gains and losses
are included in the statement of changes in net assets available for benefits in net investment income. These
instruments involve market and/or credit risk in excess of the amount recognized in the statement of net assets
available for benefits. Risks arise from the possible inability of counterparties to meet the terms of their
contracts and from movement in currency and securities values and interest rates. The net fair value of open
forward exchange contracts (receivable and payable) as of December 31, 2024 and 2023 was $(905,173) and
$(988,802), respectively.

8. Actuarial Present Value of Accumulated Plan Benefits
Accumulated Plan benefits are those future periodic payments that are attributable under the Plan’s provisions
to the service employees have rendered. Accumulated Plan benefits include benefits expected to be paid to (a)
retired or terminated employees or their beneficiaries, (b) beneficiaries of employees who have died and (c)
present employees or their beneficiaries. Benefits payable under all circumstances - retirement, death and
termination of employment - are included to the extent they are deemed attributable to employee service
rendered to the valuation date.
The actuarial present value of accumulated Plan benefits is determined by an actuarial firm and is the amount
that results from applying actuarial assumptions to adjust the accumulated Plan benefits to reflect the time value
of money (through discounts for interest) and the probability of payment (by means of decrements such as for
death, disability, withdrawal or retirement) between the valuation date and the expected date of payment. The
computations of the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits were made as of January 1, 2024 and
2023. Had the valuations been performed at December 31, there would be no material differences.
The significant actuarial assumptions used in the valuations as of December 31, 2023 were:
2023
Life expectancy of participants Pri-2012 with a 0.94 multiplier using projection Scale
MP-2021 adjusted to reflect the bank’s mortality expectations
Average retirement age 63
Withdrawal rate Rates vary as a function of age and length of service
Discount rate for benefit obligations 6.50%
Average rate of return 6.50%
The foregoing actuarial assumptions are based on the presumption that the Plan will continue. Were the Plan to
terminate, different actuarial assumptions and other factors might be applicable in determining the actuarial
present value of accumulated Plan benefits.

9. Federal Income Tax Status
The IRS issued a determination letter dated January 5, 2021 informing the Corporation that the Plan provisions
subject to the determination letter met the applicable requirements of Internal Revenue Code (IRC) Section
401(a) for favorable tax treatment. This determination letter covers certain prior amendments to and
restatement of the Plan. The Plan has been amended since receiving this determination letter. The Plan
Administrator believes the Plan is being operated in compliance with the applicable requirements of the IRC
and, therefore, believes that the Plan is qualified and the related trust is tax exempt.
The Plan was under a periodic review by the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL) which concluded in 2023. No
material remedial actions were identified as a result of the review.
GAAP requires Plan management to evaluate tax positions taken by the Plan and recognize a tax liability (or
asset) if it has taken an uncertain position that more likely than not would not be sustained upon examination by
the IRS. Plan management has analyzed the tax positions taken, and has concluded that as of December 31,
2024 and 2023, there are no uncertain tax positions taken or expected to be taken that would require recognition
of a liability (or asset) or disclosure in the financial statements. The Plan is subject to routine audits by taxing
jurisdictions; however, there are currently no audits for any tax periods in progress.
10. Plan Termination
Although it has not expressed any intention to do so, the Corporation has the right under the Plan to discontinue
its contributions at any time and to terminate the Plan subject to the provisions set forth in ERISA.
In the event the Plan terminates, the net assets of the Plan will be allocated in a manner that is consistent with
the order of precedence as prescribed by Section 4044 of ERISA and any applicable rules and regulations
thereunder and the rules and regulations of the PBGC.
Certain benefits under the Plan are insured by the PBGC if the Plan terminates. Generally, the PBGC
guarantees most vested normal retirement age benefits, early retirement benefits and certain disability and
survivors’ benefits. However, the PBGC does not guarantee all types of benefits under the Plan and the amount
of benefit protection is subject to certain limitations.
Vested benefits under the Plan are guaranteed at the level in effect on the date of the Plan’s termination.
However, there is a statutory ceiling which is adjusted periodically on the amount of an individual’s monthly
benefit that the PBGC guarantees. That ceiling applies to those participants who elect to receive the benefits in
the form of a single-life annuity and are at least 65 years of age at the time of retirement or Plan termination,
whichever comes later. For younger annuitants or for those who elect to receive their benefits in some form
more valuable than a single-life annuity, the corresponding ceilings are actuarially adjusted downward.
Whether all participants receive their benefits, should the Plan terminate at some future time, will depend on the
sufficiency, at that time, of the Plan’s net assets to provide for those benefits and may also depend on the level
of benefits guaranteed by the PBGC.
11. Related Party and Parties-In-Interest Transactions
As of December 31, 2024 and 2023, the Plan held investments in Bank of America Corporation Common Stock
totaling $386,480,170 and $298,725,661, respectively. The Plan earned dividends thereon of $8,836,382 and
$8,176,653 for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively.
The Plan paid Trustee direct expenses to BANA totaling $583,897 and $577,090 for the years ended December
31, 2024 and 2023, respectively.

participants are excluded from the Statement of Changes in Net Assets Available for Benefits.
13. Subsequent Events
In preparing the Plan’s financial statements, subsequent events and transactions were evaluated for potential
recognition through September 24, 2025, the date the financial statements were available to be issued. Plan
management determined that there are no subsequent events or transactions that require disclosure to or
adjustment in the financial statements.

Forms of payment Preretirement Spouse Benefits are payable only as described
above. Normal retirement pension benefits are paid as described
above as a single life annuity, if the participant has no spouse as
of the date payments begin, or if the participant so elects.
Otherwise, benefits are paid in the form of 50% joint and survivor
annuity option or, if the participant elects and the spouse
consents, another actuarially equivalent optional form offered by
the plan. Optional forms are a lump sum, 50%, 75% or 100%
joint and survivor annuity, a five or ten-year certain and life
annuity, or a full cash refund annuity.
Basis for actuarial equivalence conversion from normal form of
payment to optional forms of payment is the 417(e) Mortality
Table and interest rates equal to the applicable PPA segment
rates with look-back to the September immediately preceding
commencement.

Revenue Code. The plan provides for increasing the dollar limits
automatically as such changes become effective. Increases in
the dollar limits are assumed for determining pension cost but not
for determining contributions.

The most recent amendment reflected in the following plan provisions was effective November 13,

Covered employees Any employee hired before January 1, 2006, who is employed by
an employer on a “full-time”, “prime-time” or “regular part-time”
basis shall become eligible according to the following criteria:
Before effective date: Employees who were prior plan
participants shall continue as participants in this plan.
After effective date: Employees become participants on the first
of the month coinciding with or next following the attainment of
age 21 and completion of one year of employment with 1,000
hours of service.
SSBA: SSBA became a participating employer in The Bank of
America Pension Plan for Legacy MBNA as of January 1, 1992.
SSBA participants receive credit under the MBNA plan for their
SSBA service for eligibility and vesting purposes.
SSBA participants begin accruing benefit service on January 1,
1992. Effective January 1, 2002, for employees of MBNA on
January 1, 2001, benefit service begins on date of participation
as though always employed at MNBA
Transfers from MNC Financial: There are special rules for MBNA
employees who transferred to MBNA from MNC Financial after
January 29, 1991 and before January 29, 1992. These
employees receive credit under The Bank of America Pension
Plan for Legacy MBNA for their MNC service as if they had
transferred as of January 29, 1991. Also, since they are treated
as terminated from MNC, their MBNA benefits will be offset by
their MNC deferred vested benefits, as applicable.

Preretirement death Death before attainment of eligibility for Early Retirement:
A benefit to the spouse calculated as if the participant had
separated from service on date of death, survived until age 50 (or
the date of death, if later), retired and elected a 50% Joint and
Survivor Annuity and then died the day after benefits
commenced. This benefit is payable for the lifetime of the
spouse beginning on what would have been the participant’s 50th
birthday or the date of death if later. A lump sum payment is
permitted.
Death after attainment of eligibility for Early Retirement:
If the participant is married, the spouse will receive a monthly
benefit equal to 100% of the benefit the participant would have
received had the participant retired on the day preceding death
and elected a Joint and 100% Survivor Option.
If the Participant is not married, the beneficiary (or the estate) will
receive the benefit that would have been payable had the
participant retired on the day preceding death, and elected to
receive benefits under the payment option which provides
benefits for the participant’s remaining lifetime with 120 payments
guaranteed.
Other Plan Provisions
Forms of payment Preretirement spouse benefits are payable only as described
above. Normal retirement pension benefits are paid as described
above as a single life annuity, if the participant has no spouse as
of the date payments begin, or if the participant so elects.
Otherwise, benefits are paid in the form of 50% joint and survivor
annuity option or, if the participant elects and the spouse
consents, another actuarially equivalent optional form offered by
the plan. Optional forms are a lump sum up to $20,000, 75% or
100% joint and survivor annuity to spouse, 50% or 75% joint and
survivor annuity to descendants under the age of 20, a ten-year
certain and life annuity, a level income option, or if married, a life
annuity.
Basis for actuarial equivalence conversion from normal form of
payment to optional forms of payment is the 417(e) Mortality
Table and interest rates equal to the applicable PPA segment
rates with look-back to the September immediately preceding
commencement.

(b) Survived to earliest retirement date (or date of death, if later),
(c) Started payment with a 50% joint and survivor option in effect, and
(d) Died on the following day.
Employees with age plus service totaling at least 80:
The death benefit earned for credited service before December 31, 2003 is
a life annuity determined as if the member had retired and elected a 100%
joint and survivor option with no reduction for early retirement. The death
benefit earned for credited service after December 31, 2003 is the same as
for employees with age plus service totaling less than 80.

Cost of living adjustment For members who retired before January 1, 1976, pensions are increased

granted retirees with dates of retirement prior to 1995 benefit increases
ranging from 2.2% to 7.3% (depending on years since retirement) with a $10
monthly minimum increase.

the plan after January 1, 2008

Employee in connection with any qualified pension, profit sharing

Average earnings A participant’s average annual compensation for the 60
consecutive full calendar months of employment in the last 120
months immediately preceding his last day of employment which
results in the highest such average (for the purpose of
determining the offset 36 is substituted for 60 months and annual
compensation is limited by the taxable wage base).

who retires on NRD is equal to (a) minus (b), multiplied by (c)
where

(b) is 0.65% of the lesser of Average Earnings and Covered
Compensation (the offset)

Monthly preretirement 50% of the monthly pension benefit as of the date of death,
death benefit reduced for the 50% joint and survivor election and reduced for
payment as early as the participant’s 55th birthday.

Plan Sponsor: Bank of America Corporation
Valuation Date: January 1, 2024

SCHEDULE SB ATTACHMENTS
Early retirement Monthly pension benefit determined as of early retirement date,
reduced by 1/180th for each of the first 60 consecutive months
and by 1/360th for each of the next 60 consecutive months that
the date of commencement precedes the NRD. If a participant
has 30 or more Years of Service, the fractions “1/300th” and
“1/600th” shall be substituted above for “1/180th” and “1/360th”
respectively. The offset is reduced 2/3rds of 1% for the first 36
months and 1/3rd of 1% for the next 84 months by which the date
of commencement precedes the NRD.
Effective January 1, 1999, a Participant who terminates as an
active employee on or after December 31, 1998, and who has
attained the age 62 or older shall be entitled to an Early
Retirement Benefit equal to 100% of such Participant’s vested
Accrued Benefit determined unreduced for commencement prior
to his NRD.
Postponed retirement A participant who retires on a Postponed Retirement Date will be
entitled to the larger of the actuarial equivalent of the Normal
Retirement Benefit computed as of the Participant’s NRD or his
benefit at his Postponed Retirement Date using earnings, service
and Covered Compensation as of that date.
Vested termination Monthly pension benefit determined as of termination date,
payable at NRD.
Disablement Monthly pension benefit payable at age 65 and based on his
Average Earnings and Covered Compensation at the time of
disability and the Credited Years of Service he would have
completed if he had continued in employment until NRD.
Preretirement death If a vested participant dies before benefit commencement and is
survived by his spouse, then the surviving spouse is entitled to
receive a lifetime pension equal to 50% of what the participant
would have received had he retired on the later of age 55 and
date of death. The spouse pension is deferred to the
participant’s 55th birthday if death occurs before that date.
Supplemental death benefit If a participant retires under normal, early or disability retirement
and subsequently dies, the beneficiary will receive a $5,000 lump
sum death benefit.

EIN / PN: 56-0906609/001
Plan Sponsor: Bank of America Corporation
Valuation Date: January 1, 2024

SCHEDULE SB ATTACHMENTS
Form of payment Bank of America participants: 25% of participants who retire on or after
age 55 elect an annuity (life annuity if single and 50% J&S if married);
all others elect a lump sum
Fleet and U.S. Trust cash balance participants: 25% of participants
who retire on or after age 55 elect an annuity; all others elect a lump
sum
Fleet traditional and MBNA participants: Single life annuity
U.S. Trust traditional, LaSalle and Countrywide participants: Single life
annuity if single and 50% J&S if married
Percent married 100%. Used to value pre-retirement survivor benefits and in
determining the optional forms expected to be elected at
commencement
Spouse age Wife three years younger than husband
At-risk assumptions For at-risk calculations, all participants eligible to elect benefits during
the current and subsequent ten plan years are assumed to commence
benefits at the earliest possible date under the plan, but not before the
end of the current plan year, except in accordance with the regular
valuation assumptions. In addition, all participants (not just those
eligible to begin benefits within the next 11 years) are assumed to elect
the most valuable form of benefit under the plan, which is usually the
lump sum form.
Timing of benefit payments Annuity payments are payable monthly at the beginning of the month
and lump sum payments are payable on date of decrement (for legacy
Bank of America terminations 20% are assumed to defer lump sum
payment to age 65).

Plan Sponsor: Bank of America Corporation

SCHEDULE SB ATTACHMENTS
Methods
Valuation date First day of plan year
Funding target Present value of accrued benefits as required by regulations under
IRC §430.
Target normal cost Present value of benefits expected to accrue during the plan year
plus plan-related expenses expected to be paid from plan assets
during the plan year as required by regulations under IRC §430.
Actuarial value of assets for Equal to the market value of assets as of the valuation date plus
determining minimum required the discounted present value of contributions made after the
contributions valuation date for the 2023 plan year, discounted using the
effective interest rate for the 2023 plan year.
All benefits described in the Plan Provisions section of this report
Benefits not valued
were valued. WTW has reviewed the plan provisions with Bank of
America Corporation and, based on that review, is not aware of any
significant benefits required to be valued that were not.
The plan pays small benefits (with a present value up to $5,000) in
a single lump sum payment. Such lump sums are not explicitly
valued as such; rather such participant’s benefits are valued using
the benefit choice assumptions described above.
Source of Prescribed Methods
Funding methods The methods used for funding purposes as described in Appendix A,
including the method of determining plan assets, are “prescribed
methods set by law”, as defined in the actuarial standards of practice
(ASOPs). These methods are required by IRC §430, or were selected
by the plan sponsor from a range of methods permitted by IRC §430.
Changes in Assumptions and Methods
Change in assumptions The segment interest rates and mortality used to calculate the funding
since prior valuation target and target normal cost were updated to the current valuation date
as required by IRC 430.
The cash balance interest crediting rate assumptions were changed as
described below to better reflect interest rate expectations:
• BAC Post-2007 Cash Balance and U.S. Trust Cash Balance: from
4.20% to 4.55%
